results.headline: The Future Is So Dark, Pack a Lamp
results.summary_short: “Beneath the Harvest Sky” tells the story of two teenagers in a Maine town on the Canadian border, facing limited choices and desperate to find a way out.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beneath The Harvest Sky

results.headline: To the Manner Born?
results.summary_short: “Belle” is a period film in the Merchant-Ivory style about a biracial woman raised as part of a lord and lady’s family in 18th-century England.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Belle

results.headline: A Penis With a Mind of Its Own
results.summary_short: Be careful what you wish for: A man tired of the way his lust runs his life ends up with a renegade, human-form penis in the sex farce “Bad Johnson.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bad Johnson

results.headline: Capturing an Elusive Troubadour
results.summary_short: The subtitle of the documentary “Apocalypse: A Bill Callahan Tour Film” covers the facts.
results.display_title: Apocalypse: A Bill Callahan Tour Film

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Apocalypse: A Bill Callahan Tour Film

results.headline: Hey, Evildoers, Here’s Webbing in Your Eye
results.summary_short: Peter Parker wrestles with relationship troubles between bouts with the Green Goblin and Gwen Stacy in “The Amazing Spider-Man 2,” which introduces Jamie Foxx as the villain Electro.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Amazing Spider-Man 2

results.headline: The Mysterious Adventure of the Good Night’s Sleep
results.summary_short: In “Altered States of Plaine,” the protagonist finds himself in a new location, without any sense of how he got there, any time he dozes off.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Altered States of Plaine

results.headline: Nicaragua: In Shadows of Pain and Glory
results.summary_short: “Magic Words (Breaking a Spell),” from the director Mercedes Moncada Rodríguez, is a meditation on Nicaraguan history.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Magic Words (Breaking A Spell)

results.headline: Hot Flashes? Great News.
results.summary_short: The director Henry Jaglom, whose films feel like gatherings of old friends, takes on menopause in “The M Word,” starring Tanna Frederick.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The M Word

results.headline: A Caper by the Coens, With a Fake Monet
results.summary_short: “Gambit,” a remake of the 1966 art caper that starred Michael Caine and Shirley MacLaine, was written by the Coen brothers and stars Colin Firth and Cameron Diaz.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gambit

results.headline: Something’s Burning, and Comedy Isn’t Pretty
results.summary_short: Pain in everywhere in “Ape,” a knife-edged portrait of a struggling stand-up by Joel Potrykus that looks at the allure of humiliation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ape

results.headline: Searching for the Life That Belonged to a Body
results.summary_short: In “Who Is Dayani Cristal?,” Gael García Bernal traces the footsteps of a man who died in a desert trying to cross into the United States.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Who is Dayani Cristal?

results.headline: Enemies One Year, Teammates the Next
results.summary_short: “We Could Be King” recounts an arduous struggle to combine two football teams after a budget shortfall that led to widespread school closings in Philadelphia.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Could Be King

results.headline: Possessed by Demons, and a Nutty Professor
results.summary_short: In “The Quiet Ones,” a professor and his aides experiment with a possible cure for a haunted young woman in an isolated house.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Quiet Ones

results.headline: A Female Cooperative Based on Revenge
results.summary_short: In “The Other Woman,” a comedy directed by Nick Cassavetes, Cameron Diaz plays a lawyer who learns that her lover is not only married, but has other girlfriends as well.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Other Woman

results.headline: Mom, That Fugitive Nazi Is Making Eyes at Me
results.summary_short: “The German Doctor,” directed by Lucía Puenzo from her own novel, imagines Josef Mengele’s time in South America and his interest in an Argentine family.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The German Doctor

results.headline: Into Africa
results.summary_short: Sylvia Caminer’s “Tanzania: A Journey Within” documents a trip a young American woman takes with her Tanzanian friend, back to his homeland.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tanzania: A Journey Within

results.headline: A Rocket Is Aimed at Detroit (Run! Jump!)
results.summary_short: “Brick Mansions,” directed by Camille Delamarre, comes tantalizingly close to being a high-impact allegory of race, class and real estate in a postindustrial, new-Gilded Age America.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brick Mansions

results.headline: Gone Fishing With Dad, Often on Silent Mode
results.summary_short: “Marvin, Seth and Stanley,” written and directed by Stephen Gurewitz, aims to be a deadpan travels-with-my-wacky-dad story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marvin, Seth and Stanley

results.headline: Just an After-School Job
results.summary_short: “Young & Beautiful,” by François Ozon, looks at adolescent female sexuality in a tale of a middle-class teenager who chooses to be a prostitute.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jeune et Jolie

results.headline: No Time for Audiobooks: He’s on the Road to His Destiny
results.summary_short: “Locke,” a drama starring Tom Hardy, is set almost entirely within a car in a hypnotic landscape.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Locke
